watering: Allow soil to dry out completely between waterings. Typically every 2-4 weeks, less in winter. Overwatering is the biggest risk.
sunlight: Thrives in bright, indirect light but tolerates low light conditions very well. Avoid direct, intense afternoon sun.
fertilizing: Feed once during the spring and once in the summer with a balanced liquid houseplant fertilizer (e.g., 10-10-10) diluted to half strength.

watering: Water when the top 1-2 inches of soil are dry. Leaves will begin to droop slightly when thirsty. Avoid soggy soil.
sunlight: Prefers medium to bright, indirect sunlight. Can survive in low light, but variegation may fade. Direct sun can scorch the leaves.
fertilizing: Apply a general-purpose houseplant fertilizer once a month during the spring and summer growing season. Reduce to every 6-8 weeks in fall/winter.

watering: Water thoroughly until it drains from the bottom, then allow the top 2-3 inches of soil to dry out. Usually once a week to every 10 days.
sunlight: Requires bright, filtered light. Place near a south or west-facing window, ensuring the sun's rays are not directly hitting the leaves for too long.
fertilizing: Fertilize with a high-nitrogen liquid fertilizer every two weeks during the spring and summer. Stop fertilizing in the fall and winter.

watering: Highly drought-tolerant. Water infrequentlyâ€”only when the soil is completely dry. Less is always more. Can go 3-5 weeks without water.
sunlight: Tolerates very low light, but grows best in bright, indirect light. It's one of the best low-light plants.
fertilizing: Fertilizing is rarely necessary. If you choose to, use a balanced liquid fertilizer once or twice a year during the warm months.
